S4.T1.caption: Table 1: Ablation analysis of our approach
S4.T1.table:
Method ℒC​Esubscriptℒ𝐶𝐸\mathcal{L}_{CE} ℒBℳsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{M}} ℒBℳ​𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{MA}} ℒB𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{A}} All Y/N Number Other
GGE ✓ 56.08 86.64 22.15 49.38
C​O​Bℳ𝐶𝑂superscript𝐵ℳCOB^{\mathcal{M}} ✓ ✓ 57.03 87.17 26.67 49.57
C​O​Bℳ​𝒜𝐶𝑂superscript𝐵ℳ𝒜COB^{\mathcal{MA}} ✓ ✓ 56.77 86.84 24.83 49.75
C​O​Bℳ,ℳ​𝒜𝐶𝑂superscript𝐵ℳℳ𝒜COB^{\mathcal{M,MA}} ✓ ✓ ✓ 57.49 86.57 30.12 49.77
C​O​B𝐶𝑂𝐵COB ✓ ✓ ✓ ✓ 57.53 88.36 28.81 49.27
references:
Our constraint formulation ℒBsubscriptℒ𝐵\mathcal{L}_{B} consists of three loss terms ℒBℳsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{M}}, ℒB𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{A}} and ℒBℳ​𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{MA}}, equation 12. To understand the importance of each of these loss terms, we ablate them individually in the constraint and re-train the COB model. For the model with only ℒBℳsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{M}} loss, i.e. C​O​Bℳ𝐶𝑂superscript𝐵ℳCOB^{\mathcal{M}}, the answering accuracy is 57.03%percent57.0357.03\%, better than the baseline GGE model, as shown in Table 1. This shows that increasing information content (or minimizing the redundancy) of the joint features helps VQA performance.
C​O​Bℳ​𝒜𝐶𝑂superscript𝐵ℳ𝒜COB^{\mathcal{MA}}, that contains the constraint term ℒBℳ​𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{MA}}, forces the model to learn an alignment between the answer and the joint features in the projected Barlow space while maintaining the decorrelation between the feature components. The gradients from ℒBℳ​𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{MA}} provide an additional supervision along with ℒC​Esubscriptℒ𝐶𝐸\mathcal{L}_{CE} to help the underlying joint embedding space mkfsubscriptsuperscript𝑚𝑓𝑘m^{f}_{k} to learn features relevant to the answer, resulting in an answering performance of 56.77%percent56.7756.77\%, Table 1. Combining the these two constraint terms, ℒBℳsuperscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{M}} and ℒBℳ​𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{MA}}, in C​O​Bℳ,ℳ​𝒜𝐶𝑂superscript𝐵ℳℳ𝒜COB^{\mathcal{M,MA}} results in an increased performance of 57.49%percent57.4957.49\%. Finally, C​O​B𝐶𝑂𝐵COB model contains all three loss terms, the additional ℒB𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{A}} improves the information content of the answer embedding. This further assists the ℒBℳ​𝒜superscriptsubscriptℒ𝐵ℳ𝒜\mathcal{L}_{B}^{\mathcal{MA}} loss to learn a better alignment between the less redundant joint and the answer embedding spaces, outperforming the other three ablated baselines. This ablation analysis shows that each of the three loss terms in our constraint provides a different supervision to the model and thereby improves the underlying joint representations.

We propose a new VQA regularization scheme called COB that optimizes cross-entropy loss while subjected to a redundancy minimization constraint. Cross-modal Barlow decorrelation loss as the constraint formulation promotes the alignment of the answer with image-and-question modalities while improving the information content of the underlying feature space. We propose two training policies, ATB and COB, to balance these two losses.
We show that both ATB and COB outperform the most recent SOTA GGE baseline, Table 1, on VQA-CP v2 and VQA v2 datasets for the answer prediction task. COB model also either outperforms or provides comparative results against other SOTA baselines, Table 2
without using additional annotations. Finally, Figure 6 shows that our model focuses more on the salient regions while answering the questions, hence being more interpretable.

references:
We provide performance results on two datasets, challenging VQA-CP v2[2] that has a less language bias and a standard VQA v2[13] dataset in Table 2. CSS[8] & CF-VQA[30] use counterfactual examples to overcome bias, AdvReg[35] uses regularisation techniques, HINT[40] & SCR[42] use grounding techniques, RUBi[7], LM[9] and GGE[14] use ensemble methods, GVQE [27] & DLP[21] use new encoder based method to overcome language and dataset bias. Some methods use extra annotations to improve debiasing performance, but our method does not use any extra annotations and performs better than most current state-of-the-art (SOTA) methods with better explainability in the results (see Section 5.1). Our implementation of GGE model performance is 56.08% and 58.92% on VQA-CP v2 and VQA v2 datasets respectively. In comparison our COB model, built upon the base GGE model, obtains a performance of 57.53% and 63.80%, which is an improvement of 1.45% and 4.9% respectively. We also outperform the official GGE [14] performance.
Our COB model outperforms other SOTA methods, that do not use extra annotations, for overall answer prediction task on both VQA-CP v2 and VQA v2 datasets, as presented in Table 2. We also improve overall CGD score by 0.45 units, which shows that our model is able to learn a better grounding between vision-and-language modalities.

Reasoning is an essential part of question answering, and is directly influenced by the quality of the joint representation space.
Hence it is crucial to study what the model has learned and how it processes the input data. This interpretability of a model is even more important for failure cases, in order to understand the cause of failure and model shortcomings.
We use Grad-CAM[39] as an indicative of model interpretability by computing the saliency for an image given the question and the groundtruth answer.
We analyze our COB and the SOTA baseline model [14], trained on VQA-CP v2, in the context of model interpretability in Figure 6. We observe that our model produces more interpretable regions compared to the baseline GGE model, which also indicates the reason for a higher CGD score in Table 2. For both examples, our model focuses on correct regions that are salient for answer prediction.

We propose a new VQA regularization scheme called COB that optimizes cross-entropy loss while subjected to a redundancy minimization constraint. Cross-modal Barlow decorrelation loss as the constraint formulation promotes the alignment of the answer with image-and-question modalities while improving the information content of the underlying feature space. We propose two training policies, ATB and COB, to balance these two losses.
We show that both ATB and COB outperform the most recent SOTA GGE baseline, Table 1, on VQA-CP v2 and VQA v2 datasets for the answer prediction task. COB model also either outperforms or provides comparative results against other SOTA baselines, Table 2
without using additional annotations. Finally, Figure 6 shows that our model focuses more on the salient regions while answering the questions, hence being more interpretable.

S5.T3.caption: Table 3: Projector dimensionality (NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B}) selection: PCA energy for top-k𝑘k components for different Barlow projection (bθBsubscript𝑏subscript𝜃𝐵b_{\theta_{B}}) dimensions.
references:
Zbontar and Jing et al.[46] show that increase in the projector’s (bθBsubscript𝑏subscript𝜃𝐵b_{\theta_{B}}) output dimensions (NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B})
improves the input self-supervised feature space.
However, for our Barlow decorrelation constraint we found that larger projection spaces, 𝒟B→ℝℕ𝔹​ for ​NB∈{1024,2048,4096}→superscript𝒟𝐵superscriptℝsubscriptℕ𝔹 for subscript𝑁𝐵102420484096\mathcal{D}^{B}\rightarrow\mathbb{R^{N_{B}}}\text{ for }N_{B}\in\{1024,2048,4096\}, have more redundant components. To analyse this, we compute the PCA eigen values for the representations for higher projection spaces, as shown in Table 3. We observe that top-512 components can preserve ∼99%similar-toabsentpercent99\sim 99\% of total energy of the embedding space
and hence we choose NB=512subscript𝑁𝐵512N_{B}=512 as the projection dimension for all three Barlow projectors (i.e. bθBM,bθBA,bθBM​Asubscript𝑏subscript𝜃subscript𝐵𝑀subscript𝑏subscript𝜃subscript𝐵𝐴subscript𝑏subscript𝜃subscript𝐵𝑀𝐴b_{\theta_{B_{M}}},b_{\theta_{B_{A}}},b_{\theta_{B_{MA}}}). As shown in Figure 7, NB=512subscript𝑁𝐵512N_{B}=512 also yields the maximal answering accuracy compared to other values of NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B}, which reaffirms our choice. In supplementary, we provide more ablation analysis and pseudo-code for our methods.

Selection of NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} : NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} is the output dimensionality of the Barlow projectors (bθBM,bθBA,bθBM​Asubscript𝑏subscript𝜃subscript𝐵𝑀subscript𝑏subscript𝜃subscript𝐵𝐴subscript𝑏subscript𝜃subscript𝐵𝑀𝐴b_{\theta_{B_{M}}},b_{\theta_{B_{A}}},b_{\theta_{B_{MA}}}). It is an important hyperparameter, as a too-small value to NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} leads to a smaller Barlow space where the multiple semantic concepts would be required to be modelled by the same feature component, and a too-large value would cause multiple feature components to model the same semantic concept. These two cases result in inferior performances, as shown in Figure 7 in the main paper. To select a good value of NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B} we use a PCA analysis. We compute the cumulative energy of the top-k eigenvectors on a subset of VQA-CP v2 test set using our COB model for different values of projector dimension (NBsubscript𝑁𝐵N_{B}). From Figure 13, we observe that 512 eigenvectors contains at least 98.8% of total PCA energy for NB≤4096subscript𝑁𝐵4096N_{B}\leq 4096. Hence, we chose NB=512subscript𝑁𝐵512N_{B}=512 for all our experiments. Figure 13 supplements the Table 3 in the main paper.

Ananlysis on the amount of pretraining for ATB:
Here, we extend Section 4.2 of the main paper. In Table 4, we present additional VQA results using our ATB model for different pretraining epochs, n𝑛n. We evaluate on different types of questions sets from the VQA-CP v2 [2] dataset, namely: Y/N, Number, and Other, along with the overall results on all of these sets.

Notation Meaning

evsubscript𝑒𝑣e_{v} Pretrained image encoder, parameters not updated during training.

ℒC​Esubscriptℒ𝐶𝐸\mathcal{L}_{CE} Cross-entropy loss, in general Categorical loss. For GGE [14], it is binary-cross entropy loss.

Pt0.A4.T7.caption: Table 7: Glossary of notations: Definition of the notations used in the main manuscript and supplementary. (Continuation of table 5.)
Pt0.A4.T7.table:
Notation Meaning
ℒBℳsubscriptsuperscriptℒℳ𝐵\mathcal{L}^{\mathcal{M}}_{B} A unimodal Barlow decorrelation loss for joint image-question embedding space (𝒟Msuperscript𝒟𝑀\mathcal{D}^{M}).
ℒB𝒜subscriptsuperscriptℒ𝒜𝐵\mathcal{L}^{\mathcal{A}}_{B} A unimodal Barlow decorrelation loss for answer space (𝒟Asuperscript𝒟𝐴\mathcal{D}^{A}).
ℒBℳ​𝒜subscriptsuperscriptℒℳ𝒜𝐵\mathcal{L}^{\mathcal{MA}}_{B} A multimodal Barlow decorrelation loss between the joint image-question embedding space (𝒟Msuperscript𝒟𝑀\mathcal{D}^{M}) and answer space (𝒟Asuperscript𝒟𝐴\mathcal{D}^{A}).
ℒBsubscriptℒ𝐵\mathcal{L}_{B} Overall Barlow decorrelation loss.
ℒa​l​lb​a​s​esubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙subscript𝑙𝑏𝑎𝑠𝑒\mathcal{L}_{all_{base}} Baseline (naive) implementation of overall (categorical ++ Barlow decorrelation) losses.
n𝑛n Number of pretraining epochs (with categorical loss ℒC​Esubscriptℒ𝐶𝐸\mathcal{L}_{CE}) before applying barlow decorrelatin loss (ℒBsubscriptℒ𝐵\mathcal{L}_{B}), in Align then Barlow (ATB) formulation.
ℒa​l​lA​T​Bsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙subscript𝑙𝐴𝑇𝐵\mathcal{L}_{all_{ATB}} Overall loss formulation for ATB training policy.
ℒa​l​lC​O​Bsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙subscript𝑙𝐶𝑂𝐵\mathcal{L}_{all_{COB}} Our overall constrained optimization formulation (i.e. categorical loss constrained with Barlow (COB) decorrelation loss formulation).
λ𝜆\lambda A learnable Lagrange multiplier to weight categorical loss ℒC​Esubscriptℒ𝐶𝐸\mathcal{L}_{CE} and Barlow decorrelation loss ℒBsubscriptℒ𝐵\mathcal{L}_{B}.
κ𝜅\kappa It is a tolerance hyperparameter to control the change in λ𝜆\lambda, give the value of Barlow decorrelation loss ℒBsubscriptℒ𝐵\mathcal{L}_{B} at iteration t𝑡t.
ℂℂ\mathbb{C} Barlow constraint defined as difference between ℒBsubscriptℒ𝐵\mathcal{L}_{B} and κ𝜅\kappa. When it becomes zero the change in λ𝜆\lambda becomes negative. This subsequently forces the dynamic weigth λ𝜆\lambda assigned to constraint to decrease.
ℂtsubscriptℂ𝑡\mathbb{C}_{t} Constraint ℂℂ\mathbb{C} at iteration t𝑡t.
λtsubscript𝜆𝑡\lambda_{t} value of λ𝜆\lambda at iteration t𝑡t.
ℒa​l​lC​O​Bλsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙subscript𝑙𝐶𝑂superscript𝐵𝜆\mathcal{L}_{all_{COB^{\lambda}}} Lagrangian form of overall constrained optimization ℒa​l​lC​O​Bsubscriptℒ𝑎𝑙subscript𝑙𝐶𝑂𝐵\mathcal{L}_{all_{COB}}.
△​λt△subscript𝜆𝑡\triangle\lambda_{t} Change in λ𝜆\lambda in iteration t𝑡t.
references: A glossary of all the mathematical notation used in the main paper and supplementary can be found in Table 5, 7.
